scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of correspondence of the Twyman family with friends and relatives. The papers include letters, 1861-1865, from Walker G. Twyman, with the 19th Virginia Infantry, describing battles, marches and conditions in Virginia camps and Chimborazo Hospital, Richmond, Virginia. Specific Civil War topics include Charlottesville troops at Harper's Ferry; Camp Pickens; battle at Fairfax Court House; execution of spies; 1st Manassas; rumors, picket duty; Seven Days' Battles; prisoners dying of typhoid at Chimborazo; sending of food and supplies to soldiers; and fighting at Gordonsville. Other topics include the settlement of an estate in Albemarle County, Va.; a Virginia Central Railroad Company Report on inability to pay a divident; a baptism in an Earlysville Baptist church; an ailing child with "curved spine"; the sale of a slave in poor health; and bail for Charles [Watts ?] in Lexington, Ky.

did.unittitle:
Letters of Garret Watts (Husband of Martha Twyman Watts--daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Twyman)
1837-1855
Lexington, Ky. -- to Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Twyman (in-laws) at Longwood P.O., Albemarle County June 28, 1837

scopecontent.p: mentions problem concerning raising bail to release Charles from jail and have him move immediately to Kentucky from Virginia-fears Charles life may be in danger; mentions marriage of Lucy Watts to Walter G. Ferguson, a grandson of Walter Carr, formerly of Albemarle County.

did.unittitle: Lexington, Ky --to in-laws in Albemarle County July 29, 1838

scopecontent.p: --concerning illness of son William who is being treated for "curved spine;" talks of details of will of $20,000 to $30,000 he is handling for deceased husband of Mrs.[Beverly] Broadus.

did.unittitle: Lexington, Ky.--to in-laws in Albemarle County June 30, 1839

scopecontent.p: William still ill and not expected to recover; tells specifics of sale of Albert, a slave, for $700; Albert's poor health lowered his selling price, but he was sold without "warranty" so "if he should become worse and die the purchaser can not come back on me"; has received a letter from Charles indicating he has arrived at his home safely.

did.unittitle: Lexington, Ky.-- to parents in Albemarle County from daughter, Martha Twyman Watts Sep 29, 1839

scopecontent.p: William worsening; Lucy Ferguson and husband living at their home

did.unittitle: from Fayette City, Ky. To Joseph W. Twyman, Earlysville,Va. Jan 10-19, 1851

scopecontent.p: Two letters concerning will executions

did.unittitle: from Fayette City, Ky.-to Joseph W.. Twyman Apr 27 1851
from Fayette City, Ky. --to Joseph W. Twyman, Earlysville, Va. Oct 7, 1851

scopecontent.p: wants Twyman to fix date in November for settlement of his father's estate.

did.unittitle: Civil War Letters of Walker G. Twyman (Sergeant--Co. B--19th Regiment Virginia Volunteers) Feb 2 1858
Charlottesville to brother Billy (William R. Twyman ) Feb 2 1858

scopecontent.p: Charlottesville to brother Billy (William R. Twyman)

did.unittitle: Charlottesville to sister Sallie Oct 25 1859

scopecontent.p: describing a baptizing in a Baptist church in Earlysville

did.unittitle: Charlottesville to sister Sallie Dec 20 1859

scopecontent.p: mentions that everyone is full of "military spirit" and that he has joined a new company - all rifle

did.unittitle: Harper's Ferry to Billy Feb 26 1861

scopecontent.p: full of interesting details about troop trip from Charlottesville via Gordonsville to Harper's Ferry, where Federals had just left having not heard of the passing of the ordinance of Secession - describes train of powder left by Union forces which was ignited, blowing up buildings containing arms; describes hearing rumors that Lincoln had left Washington; gives troop numbers at Harper's Ferry; tells of the troops walking from Strasburg to Winchester and the ills they suffered; tells of the hoisting of the southern flag over Harper's Ferry; mentions being at Martinsburg where more southern troops are expected and writes of the crowded conditions there; includes a hand drawn map of positions of forces on various hills at Harper's Ferry.

did.unittitle: Camp Henry near Culpeper Court House to brother Billy May 17 1861

scopecontent.p: - talks of meeting friends from Greene County, John Williams and John Eddins; reports a great many ladies are about catching the soldiers' eyes.

did.unittitle: Camp Pickens, Manassas Station May 26 1861 through June 4 1861

scopecontent.p: This is a combination report and letter to brother Billy which covers three long pages of paper from an old accounting book with an insert letter. On May 27, he notes that there has been a false report that the enemy was within one mile of camp; on May 28, he writes that General Lee has arrived at camp from Richmond, that the Carolina regiment has encamped 8 miles away at Centreville, that one spy of the enemy has been shot and two more taken prisoners; on May 29, 200 troops from Goochland have arrived, hears that England has recognized the Confederacy; on May 30, drill times have changed, General Lee starts back to Richmond, Tom [Parish] arrives from Harper's Ferry with dispatch for General Lee, General Milledge Luke Bonham addresses troops, another spy is shot; on May 31, more troops are gathering below Fort Henry; on June 1, 450 soldiers arrive at daybreak, General Beauregard (Pierre Gustave Toutant) and General Lee come from Richmond, hears that President Jefferson Davis arrived in Richmond May 28, describes in detail battle that morning at Fairfax Court House, two companies of the first regiment of Virginia were involved, 50 of the Confederate riflemen drove back 80 federal troops, the captain of his rifle company was killed with a shot through the heart. On June 2, describes capture of more prisoners; on June 4, more prisoners taken, troops from Georgia pass through on way to Harper's Ferry; on June [5] goes to Bull Run to begin digging entrenchments. The insert letter to brother Billy on May 31 tells of a spy captured by the South Carolina regiment who had a map of encampments. He was convicted and shot.

did.unittitle: Manassas Station to brother Billy June 1 1861

scopecontent.p: tells of Generals Beauregard and Lee arriving from Richmond; repeats details of battle that A.M. at Fairfax Court House, and describes throwing up breastworks about his camp.

did.unittitle: Manassas Station to brother Billy June 3 1861

scopecontent.p: notes movements of four companies of the first regiment of Virginia companies with two or three cavalry companies moving toward Fairfax Court House; still building breastworks.

did.unittitle: Manassas Station to brother Billy June 5 1861

scopecontent.p: (written on freight way bill of the Virginia Central Railroad) - "sending my jug - keep it until I send word to send it"; writes that they have received word to pack baggage.

did.unittitle: Camp Pickens, Manassas Station to brother Billy June 5 1861

scopecontent.p: hard rain; expect to move tents "tomorrow" about four miles below present site "here on Bull Run" to nearer the railroad.

did.unittitle: advanced picket-Camp Pickens, stationed on Bull Run June 15 1861

scopecontent.p: describes being at the post since "a week ago yesterday," and his picket duty, which has been steady; some men ill; a regiment has arrived and camped one mile below on the Run; some soldiers still arriving from Harper's Ferry and other points; tells of staying up all night while on duty and listening to sounds of bull frogs, crickets and "even an owl hoot."

did.unittitle: advanced picket-Camp Pickens, stationed on Bull Run June 16 1861

scopecontent.p: another regiment arrives and stops near his camp; another goes to Charlottesville.

did.unittitle: Camp Pickens to Billy June 19 1861

scopecontent.p: soldiers still arriving; "our soldiers are progressing by degrees toward Alexandria; tells of small fight at Vienna on the Louden & Hamshire Railroad --seven Yankees killed, took forty guns and some provisions.

did.unittitle: Bull Run to Billy June 20 1861

scopecontent.p: - learns that 30 of C.S.A. men with small cannon fired on one regiment of [Bellengers] Yankees on train going up the railroad; gives account of supposed number killed at possibly 200

did.unittitle: Bull Run to Billy June 21 1861

scopecontent.p: hears that his regiment may leave in the morning for Romney

did.unittitle: Camp Pickens to Billy n.d.

scopecontent.p: thinks 8,000 troops are in the vicinity - sent a box with vest, coat and jug "with money to get the best whisky and send it down by the first chance."

did.unittitle: Centreville to Billy June 23 1861

scopecontent.p: arrived yesterday in Centerville where a whole regiment from Albemarle is present; located five miles from the camp on Bull Run; asks that Billy send the whisky and keep his letters

did.unittitle: Centreville to Billy June 29 1861

scopecontent.p: describes Centerville and "houses built before Braddock's defeat;" reflects on movements thus far --"one week on trip to Harper's Ferry; two weeks at Charlottesville; two weeks at Culpeper Court House; two weeks at Manassas Junction, and two weeks at Bull Run; gives an account of his reactions to each place; says troops are drilling hard and that there are eight roads leading from present position; false alarm in camp last night when "some of the fellows were scared out of their senses."

did.unittitle: Centreville to Billy July 4 1861

scopecontent.p: request for shirt and discussion of clothing needs

did.unittitle: Centreville to Billy July 4 1861

scopecontent.p: remarks that the accounting book paper he is writing on should last for some time

did.unittitle: Centreville to Billy July 5-9 1861

scopecontent.p: three notes with matters pertaining to requests for food and clothing

did.unittitle: Centreville to Billy July 12 1861

scopecontent.p: has been in camp three months; describes daily routine

did.unittitle: Centreville to Miss Milly July 12 1861

scopecontent.p: long letter describing his troop movements and attributes not writing to being pestered by people while on picket duty; tells of recreational activities

did.unittitle: Centreville to Billy July 17 1861

scopecontent.p: this letter is a report of daily activities through July 23--July 17, struck tents and retreated to Bull Run; July 18, fight at Mitchell's field--enemy routed; July 21, general fight with first fire opened on Latham's battery at Lewis Ford--describes fight; July 22, collecting plunder that enemy scattered; July 23, advanced almost to Centreville, describes skirmishing there--"the firing was equal to the panorama of the Russian War"

did.unittitle: Bull Run, copy of a news clipping of "Brilliant Victory Near Manassas" from the Jeffersoniannewspaper of Charlottesville July 19 1861
Bull Run to Billy July 22 1861

scopecontent.p: raining; took about 30 cannon yesterday--18 or 20 rifled canon; "I recon more men engaged in the fight than in the history of the U.S."

did.unittitle: Camp near Centreville to Sallie July 29 1861

scopecontent.p: extract from Mrs. [Hemans] Works, a long poem which "I altered to fit the times"

did.unittitle: Near Centreville to Billy Aug 2 1861

scopecontent.p: wants bread, soda and coffee; describes his cooking efforts

did.unittitle: Manassas Junction to Billy Aug 3 1861

scopecontent.p: tells of burying the dead, sending Yankee wounded (those well enough to move) to Richmond. Yankees are being buried by Confederates--thinks about 3000 Yankees killed and wounded--600 C.S.A. killed

did.unittitle: Near Centreville to Billy Aug 10 1861

scopecontent.p: has been ill and taking laudanum; received orders in the morning to be ready for marching

did.unittitle: Centreville to Billy Aug 16 1861

scopecontent.p: describes the difference between "standing still to be shot at and not shoot, and rushing up in the fight." He writes: "When the Yankees fired at us, and Latham fired at them, it was as much as the captains could do to keep the men from firing at the Yankee skirmishers. There were 10,000 Yankees in front of us and we kept them back without firing a musket except the cannon which killed 200 if not more."

did.unittitle: Centreville to Billy Aug 21 1861

scopecontent.p: everything quiet with regards to fighting

did.unittitle: Centreville to Billy Aug 22 1861

scopecontent.p: after retreat of Yankees, [Burnie] Brown's company went on the battlefield and got as much plunder as they could carry--"it shows what they are--they didn't take any part in the fight at all."

did.unittitle: Centreville to Billy Aug 26-27 1861

scopecontent.p: orders to get ready to advance have been rescinded

did.unittitle: Fairfax Court House to Billy Sept 1 1861

scopecontent.p: preparing for picket duty at a hill close to Falls Church, which C.S.A. took possession of last week

did.unittitle: Fairfax Court House to Billy Sept 3 1861

scopecontent.p: reports that when he moved from Centreville he lost all his clothes except those he had on; describes picket duty on Munson's Hill where there is scavenging for corn and potatoes to eat; lines of C.S.A. and Union pickets are 300 to 500 yards from each other--firing all the time--"I could see Yankees very plain." Location is six miles from Alexandria and D.C.

did.unittitle: Fairfax Court House to Billy Sept 13 1861

scopecontent.p: wants to hire a "free" boy to cook for him and asks Billy to find one as "cheap as you can."

did.unittitle: Fairfax Court House to Billy Sept 15 1861

scopecontent.p: going on picket duty again at Mason's Hill--more fighting about four miles this side of Washington

did.unittitle: Fairfax Court House to Billy Sept 24 1861

scopecontent.p: "I would not mind being in camp if it was not a complete waste of time."

did.unittitle: Two miles from Annandale to ? Sept 29 1861

scopecontent.p: came there with a Kentucky regiment the day before--drove back some Yankees

did.unittitle: On picket duty, to Sister Sallie Sept 30-Oct 1 1861

scopecontent.p: G. Watson Carr is now Lt. Col. (Acting Col.) of the regiment instead of Col. Strange, who is acting commander of the right in Richmond

did.unittitle: Fairfax County Court House Oct 1-8 1861

scopecontent.p: on guard at Beauregard headquarters

did.unittitle: Fairfax County Court House Oct 6 1861

scopecontent.p: wants sweet potatoes, chestnuts, and butter sent to him

did.unittitle: Fairfax County Court House, to friends and fellow citizens Oct 9-15 1861

scopecontent.p: describes escaping being hit by a ball and a small fight at Stone bridge between two Yank companies and his picket

did.unittitle: Camp near Centreville to Billy Oct 15-17 1861

scopecontent.p: tells of march to 1 mile south of Centreville where the whole force has fallen back

did.unittitle: Camp near Centreville to Billy Oct 19-27 1861
did.physloc: pitched tents on the Manassas Road; describes fight at Leesburg where about 8,000 Yankees crossed the river and met 2,500 Rebs, who drove them back, taking prisoners and artillery and other supplies

did.unittitle: Camp near Centreville to Sallie Oct 31 1861

scopecontent.p: writes about his army life and how he has adapted to it

did.unittitle: Camp near Centreville to Billy Nov 6 1861

scopecontent.p: describes three ladies passing by which caused the band to come out to play for them

did.unittitle: Camp near Centreville to Billy Nov 17 1861

scopecontent.p: reports on the building of chimneys on the tents to make them comfortable

did.unittitle: Camp near Centreville to Billy and Sallie Nov 19-Dec 2 1861

scopecontent.p: several letters with minutiae

did.unittitle: Camp near Centreville to Billy Dec 6 1861

scopecontent.p: describes a 14' by 16' house they are building which ten soldiers will live in

did.unittitle: Camp near Centreville to Bill Dec 14 1861

scopecontent.p: picket post has been changed

did.unittitle: Camp near Centreville to Sallie Dec 15 1861

scopecontent.p: writes about life in the camp, with a description of some ladies who were visiting

did.unittitle: Camp near Centreville to Bill Dec 26 1861

scopecontent.p: plenty of good food as a result of Christmas gifts

did.unittitle: Camp near Centreville to Bill Dec 31 1861

scopecontent.p: reports that he has heard Brig. Gen. [Philip St. George] Cocke has shot himself with a pistol--the "ball entering his head near one ear and coming out the other ear"

did.unittitle: Camp near Centreville to Bill Jan 20 1862

scopecontent.p: wants Bill to hire him another cook

did.unittitle: Camp near Centreville to Bill Feb 11 1862

scopecontent.p: many volunteers reenlisting

did.unittitle: Camp near Centreville to Bill Feb 15 1862

scopecontent.p: snowing, hears heavy firing on the Potomac

did.unittitle: Chimborazo Hospital, Richmond to Bill Mar 7 1862

scopecontent.p: "I was taken with mumps last Monday, sent to the hospital at Manassas on Wednesday and started to Richmond yesterday morning--got here last night. If the cars down had not been locked when I got to Gordonsville, I would have gotten out and come to Charlottesville."

did.unittitle: Chimborazo Hospital to Bill Mar 7 1862

scopecontent.p: asks Bill to see Dr. Cabell in Charlottesville and see if he can get him transferred there from Chimborazo Hospital

did.unittitle: Richmond City to Bill Mar 11 1862

scopecontent.p: is better, still awaiting reply from Dr. Cabell; expects to get a situation at the hospital as an assistant steward under William B. Ward in No. 4 at $30 per month

did.unittitle: to Sergt. W.G. Twyman from Dr. J.L. Cabell, General Hospital, Charlottesville Mar 13 1862

scopecontent.p: understands Twyman's request for a transfer but recommends that he write himself to the surgeon-general making this request

did.unittitle: copy of official permission of the CSA War Department for W.G. Twyman to visit Albemarle County April 9 1862
Chimborazo Hospital to Pa and Ma April 16 1862

scopecontent.p: describes troop movements through Richmond for Yorktown

did.unittitle: Chimborazo Hospital to Bill April 27 1862

scopecontent.p: hears hospital may be moved to Danville; has been assigned to the clerk's office in division No. 5

did.unittitle: Chimborazo Hospital to Bill May 9 1862

scopecontent.p: hears many reports circulating about killed, wounded and missing in the 19th Va.; excitement in Richmond very great.

did.unittitle: Chimborazo Hospital to Sallie June 4 1862

scopecontent.p: describes fighting around Richmond and the hard work of women of the city who are caring for the wounded

did.unittitle: Chimborazo Hospital to Billy June 5 1862

scopecontent.p: gives advice on joining the service

did.unittitle: Chimborazo Hospital to Bill and all July 2-3 1862
did.physloc: reports he has been severely ill but appears to be improving; tells of the surroinding battle, with the enemy driven back 12 to 15 miles from where the fighting commenced; gives graphic description of battle around Richmond, with comments on actions of J.B. Magruder, Jefferson Davis and Stonewall Jackson; number of killed and wounded immense and two or three hundred prisoners taken

did.unittitle: Chimborazo Hospital to Billy July 7 1862

scopecontent.p: prisoners being brought in every day and many of the sick are dying with typhoid fever

did.unittitle: Chimborazo Hospital to Sallie and Bill July 9 1862

scopecontent.p: (written on "Confederate" paper) weather very hot; patients dying fast

did.unittitle: Chimborazo Hospital to Sallie July 15 1862

scopecontent.p: tells of visit to Richmond where cost of food is exorbitant; reports that in month of June, mortality rate at the hospital was 350; about 3000 patients in the hospital

did.unittitle: Chimborazo Hospital to Bill Aug 3 1862

scopecontent.p: many wounded gone on furlough; reports return of extreme pain in his side

did.unittitle: From Chimborazo Hospital to Walker Sep 3 1862

scopecontent.p: letter from R.M. Stephens, friend, about fellow soldiers at Chimborazo

did.unittitle: From ? to Bill Sep 8 1862

scopecontent.p: tells of "Spooner" leaving his coat with William B. Ward and says he will seee about it as soon as he gets back to the hospital. "I can not get out of the house."

did.unittitle: From ? to Daddy Sep 23, 1862

scopecontent.p: reports on encounter between Jackson and Burnside near the Potomac in which Burnside was solidly beaten.
